qas.question: What agreement did Montcalm and Indians have?

context: The new British command was not in place until July. When he arrived in Albany, <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><a0_3><a0_4><b5_0><b6_0>Abercrombie<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_4/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> refused to take any significant actions until Loudoun approved them. Montcalm took bold action against his inertia. Building on Vaudreuil's work harassing the Oswego garrison, Montcalm executed a strategic feint by moving his headquarters to <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><a1_3><a1_4><b4_0>Ticonderoga<b4_0/><a1_4/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, as if to presage another attack along Lake George. With Abercrombie pinned down at Albany, Montcalm slipped away and led the successful attack on <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3><a2_4><b7_0>Oswego<b7_0/><a2_4/><a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> in August. In the aftermath, Montcalm and the Indians under his command disagreed <a3_2>about <a3_1><a3_4><b8_0>the <a3_0><a3_3>disposition of prisoners' personal effects<b8_0/><a3_4/><a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>. The Europeans did not consider them prizes and prevented the Indians from stripping the prisoners of their valuables, which angered the Indians.
